Article.ArticleTitle: Reduced photosynthetic thermal acclimation capacity under elevated ozone in poplar (Populus tremula) saplings.

AbstractText: The sensitivity of photosynthesis to temperature has been identified as a key uncertainty for projecting the magnitude of the terrestrial carbon cycle response to future climate change. Although thermal acclimation of photosynthesis under rising temperature has been reported in many tree species, whether tropospheric ozone (O<sub>3</sub> ) affects the acclimation capacity remains unknown. In this study, temperature responses of photosynthesis (light-saturated rate of photosynthesis (A<sub>sat</sub> ), maximum rates of RuBP carboxylation (V<sub>cmax</sub> ), and electron transport (J<sub>max</sub> ) and dark respiration (R<sub>dark</sub> ) of Populus tremula exposed to ambient O<sub>3</sub> (AO<sub>3</sub> , maximum of 30 ppb) or elevated O<sub>3</sub> (EO<sub>3</sub> , maximum of 110 ppb) and ambient or elevated temperature (ambient +5°C) were investigated in solardomes. We found that the optimum temperature of A<sub>sat</sub> (T<sub>optA</sub> ) significantly increased in response to warming. However, the thermal acclimation capacity was reduced by O<sub>3</sub> exposure, as indicated by decreased T<sub>optA</sub> , and temperature optima of V<sub>cmax</sub> (T<sub>optV</sub> ) and J<sub>max</sub> (T<sub>optJ</sub> ) under EO<sub>3</sub> . Changes in both stomatal conductance (g<sub>s</sub> ) and photosynthetic capacity (V<sub>cmax</sub> and J<sub>max</sub> ) contributed to the shift of T<sub>optA</sub> by warming and EO<sub>3</sub> . Neither R<sub>dark</sub> measured at 25°C ( <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msubsup><mi>R</mi> <mtext>dark</mtext> <mn>25</mn></msubsup> </math> ) nor the temperature response of R<sub>dark</sub> was affected by warming, EO<sub>3</sub> , or their combination. The responses of A<sub>sat</sub> , V<sub>cmax</sub> , and J<sub>max</sub> to warming and EO<sub>3</sub> were closely correlated with changes in leaf nitrogen (N) content and N use efficiency. Overall, warming stimulated growth (leaf biomass and tree height), whereas EO<sub>3</sub> reduced growth (leaf and woody biomass). The findings indicate that thermal acclimation of A<sub>sat</sub> may be overestimated if the impact of O<sub>3</sub> pollution is not taken into account.
